documentType: Bureau of Prisons Psychology Services Records
summary: This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from late July 2019, including clinical contacts, a disciplinary competency evaluation, and internal email correspondence. The records detail his mental state, his account of a neck injury incident in the SHU, and his preparations for a court hearing, all in the weeks leading up to his death. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychology services clinical intervention notes and a post-suicide watch report for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 24-28, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The notes detail his mental status, his claims of memory loss regarding neck injuries, his complaints about SHU conditions, and his interactions with staff and inmate companions. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service notes and assessments for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-24, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM). It details his mental health evaluations, suicide risk assessments, and daily observations, including the incident on July 23 where he was found with a string around his neck and placed on suicide watch. This document is a Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment and suicide risk evaluation for Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 9, 2019, the day after a court proceeding. It details his mental health history, current status, and risk factors, concluding he was at low acute suicide risk and not placed on suicide watch. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment and intake screening records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-10, 2019, conducted at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY/NYM). It includes suicide risk assessments, risk of sexual abusiveness evaluations, and intake interviews, all concluding Epstein was at low risk for suicide and sexual abusiveness, with no acute psychopathology.

events.title: Epstein Charged with Tattooing/Self-Mutilation
events.description: Inmate Epstein was charged with a disciplinary code violation (Code 228) for 'Tattooing or Self-Mutilation,' assigned incident report number 3282555, following an incident involving marks on his neck.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment by Dr. Imeri
events.description: Dr. Darlene Imeri conducted a suicide risk assessment where it was noted as 'unclear' if Epstein placed a string around his own neck or if someone else did.

events.title: Competency Evaluation for Disciplinary Process
events.description: Dr. Darlene Imeri evaluated Epstein and found him COMPETENT to proceed with the disciplinary process regarding the July 23 incident.

events.title: Follow-up After Removal from Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was seen by Dr. Jolle Avena for a follow-up after being removed from Psychological Observation. He reported doing well, denied suicidal ideation, and stated he was going to court for a status hearing.

events.title: Email Request for Notes on Suicide Attempt
events.description: Email correspondence between Dr. Elissa Miller and Lee Plourde regarding a request for notes on Epstein concerning a 'suicide attempt,' with a reminder about HIPAA compliance.

events.title: Epstein placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was placed on Suicide Watch following an incident involving marks on his neck, with the watch starting at 01:40.

events.title: Epstein removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was stepped down from Suicide Watch to Psychological Observation after assessment found low acute suicide risk.

events.title: Daily Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein remained on Psychological Observation with daily psychology sessions, pending housing arrangements.

events.title: Epstein discusses neck injury with psychologist
events.description: Epstein told Dr. Miller he has no memory of the event causing marks on his neck and asked to speak with former cellmate Nick.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: At about 2 AM, Epstein was found by SHU staff in his cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He was placed on Suicide Watch. The origin of the string (self-inflicted or by another) was unclear.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Psychologist Darlene Imeri conducted a Suicide Risk Assessment with Epstein at about 9:10 AM. Epstein denied remembering the incident, claimed his throat hurt, and later staff logs indicated he told staff his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller conducted an initial precautionary suicide risk assessment with Epstein after his return from court. He denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidality, or substance abuse.

events.title: Placement in SHU
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention. He expressed numerous complaints about conditions and requests to psychology staff.

events.title: Medication Issue Noted
events.description: Psychology provider Samantha DiMisa noted that Epstein had not been receiving his medication used to alleviate constipation.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attended a court proceeding. The assessment notes it 'could have given him bad news regarding his legal situation,' prompting precautionary psychological observation upon his return to the facility.

events.title: Psychological Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller conducted a comprehensive suicide risk assessment of Jeffrey Epstein after he was placed on precautionary psychological observation following his court return.

events.title: Previous Incarceration in Palm Beach
events.description: Epstein reported having previously served time in Palm Beach County jail on charges of soliciting prostitution.

events.title: Epstein Intake and Risk Assessments
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes BOP intake screening, risk of sexual abusiveness assessment, and a pre-court psychological consultation. Staff are instructed to monitor him upon return from court.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A comprehensive suicide risk assessment is conducted on Epstein following his court proceeding. He is found to have a low acute suicide risk and an absent chronic suicide risk.

events.title: Epstein's Bail Hearing Mention
events.description: During his assessment, Epstein reports he is going to have a bail hearing on Monday and believes he is going to be released from jail.

keyFacts: Epstein was found in his cell with marks on his neck on or before July 23, 2019, leading to a charge of 'Tattooing or Self-Mutilation' (Incident Report 3282555).
A psychological assessment dated July 23, 2019, stated it was 'unclear at this time if he had placed the string around his neck or if someone else did.'
Epstein repeatedly told psychologists he could not remember how he obtained the neck injuries, attributing potential memory issues to sleep deprivation from untreated sleep apnea.

Despite the incident, multiple clinical contacts from July 27-31 show Epstein consistently denied current suicidal ideation, was future-oriented, and was found competent to face disciplinary proceedings.
Internal BOP email on August 1, 2019, shows a request for notes on Epstein regarding a 'suicide attempt,' highlighting internal communication about the prior incident.
Jeffrey Epstein claimed to have no memory of the incident that caused marks and scabbing on his neck while in SHU, despite psychologists challenging his account.
Epstein expressed anxiety about returning to SHU, citing fear for his safety, noise, smells, and reported his cellmate had called him a 'pedophile'.
Psychology staff consistently noted Epstein denied current suicidal ideation, was future-oriented, and focused on his legal case.
Epstein was stepped down from Suicide Watch to Psychological Observation on July 24, 2019, after a 31-hour watch, with a low acute suicide risk assessment.
The documents show Epstein had daily legal visits, interacted with inmate companions discussing investments, and complained about conditions like limited bathroom breaks during attorney meetings.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on Suicide Watch.
Epstein denied remembering the incident and later, according to staff logs, claimed his cellmate tried to kill himâ€”a claim he did not make to the assessing psychologist.
Psychological assessments from July 9-23 consistently noted Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or substance abuse.
Epstein was assessed with risk factors for suicide including high-profile crime, lack of family connections, sex offender status, and current physical pain (sore throat).
The documents show ongoing complaints from Epstein about prison conditions (lack of spoon/soap, cold cell, uniform issues, medication) and his focus on his legal case and bail hearing.
On July 9, 2019, BOP Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having a 'Low' acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, concluding a suicide watch was not warranted.
Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, substance abuse, or past or present suicidal ideation during the assessment.

The assessment was triggered as a precaution because Epstein returned from a court proceeding on July 8, 2019, and had risk factors including a high-profile case, sex offense charges, and lack of close family connections.
Epstein was future-oriented, expressed a desire to be alive, and was optimistic about an upcoming bail hearing, believing he would be released.
Epstein was classified as a CARE1-MH inmate, indicating no significant functional impairment from mental illness and no need for regular mental health intervention.

On July 9, 2019, a BOP psychological assessment found Jeffrey Epstein to be at 'Low' overall acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, with numerous protective factors outweighing his risk factors.
Epstein was assessed as being at 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' for sexual behavior within the facility, despite a history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.
Epstein was future-oriented, denied any suicidal ideation, expressed a desire to be alive, and was focused on an upcoming bail hearing where he believed he would be released.

The assessments noted risk factors including his high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, a recent court proceeding, and lack of close family connections (only a brother with whom he had no relationship).
All evaluations concluded Epstein had no acute psychopathology, no mental health history, and was classified as CARE1-MH, indicating no need for regular mental health intervention.
